entry.title: Re: Issue with Liquidity Forecast View in Cash Flow Analy...
entry.content:
Hello @Vindhya 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Cash Flow Analyzer, Liquidity Planning with SAP Analytics Cloud, Cash Flow Analyzer

To summarise, the reason your Liquidity Forecast view shows only actual values is because the forecast data extraction hasn‚Äôt been executed or liquidity item assignments are missing. To enable it:

  • Run the Schedule Cash Flow Analyzer Data Extraction app.
  • Ensure liquidity items are properly assigned to open transactions.
  • Re-run the extraction and refresh the Liquidity Forecast view in Cash Flow Analyzer.

Once, configured, the forecast tab will show predicted cash inflows/outflows per liquidity item, complementing your actual cash flows.

Here is detailed process on how to activate forecast data extraction.

Search for Cash Flow Analyzer

Create a new extraction run. Schedule it to run ‚ÄúFor All Dates‚Äù or up to the horizon you want to forecast. Execute or schedule it daily. This populates the forecast table.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: üöÄ Cost-Based PoC for Service Contracts ‚Äì Expanded Support for Service Items
entry.content:
Co-Authored by Frank Hennrich and Volkmar Zahn  

We‚Äôre excited to announce a powerful enhancement coming with SAP S/4HANA 2025 FPS 0: support for cost-based percentage of completion (POC) revenue recognition for service contracts that include not only execution order items, but now also service items, expense items, service part items and tool items.

This enhancement brings greater flexibility and financial transparency to service contract management, enabling more accurate revenue recognition and reporting across a broader range of item types.

üåü What‚Äôs New?

Until now, cost-based POC for service contracts was only available for assigned execution order items. With this update, you can now assign service order items with the following item types to a cost-based POC service contract item:

  • Service items
  • Expense items
  • Service part items
  • Tool items

These items can now contribute to the financial performance of the contract, enabling a more comprehensive and realistic view of project progress and profitability.

You can find more information about the new feature in Event-Based Revenue Recognition for Service Contracts as Root Items in Financial Hierarchy | SAP Help.

üß© Key Configuration: Financial Hierarchy Root Item

To enable this functionality, the service contract item must be configured as a root item in the financial hierarchy. This is done by selecting the appropriate item category used during contract creation. If this checkbox is not set, the system will default to traditional time-based revenue recognition.

Once configured, the service contract item becomes the anchor for financial aggregation, allowing all assigned items to contribute to planned and actual values on contract item level.

üîç How It Works

Let us look at a use case scenario of an IT Infrastructure Maintenance Contract

An IT service provider enters into a 24-month service contract with a large enterprise client to maintain their data center infrastructure. The contract includes:

  • Service Contract Item: Covers the commercial side of the overall infrastructure maintenance.
  • Service Order Items: Represent specific maintenance tasks (e.g., Routine server check, Security patching).

Revenue Recognition Logic: Cost-Based Percentage of Completion (PoC) method is used.

Planned Revenue: Taken from the service contract item (2000 USD)

Planned Cost: Aggregated from all service orders linked to service contract items.

This scenario highlights how hierarchical cost aggregation enables accurate cost-based revenue recognition in service contracts by aligning planned revenue from billable items with actual costs from maintenance activities.

 1. Create a Service Contract Item

Define the item as a financial hierarchy root by utilizing the corresponding item category. This enables it to collect financial data from all assigned items.

2. Assign Service Contract Item to Service Order Items
You can now assign the service contract item not only to execution order items but also service items, expense items, service part items, and tool items.

3. Plan and Track Costs and Revenues
For example, a service order item with a planned cost of 1232 USD ...

... and the planned revenue of 2000 USD from the service contract item ... 

... will now be included in the contract‚Äôs financial plan.

Upon release and service confirmation, actual costs and revenues are posted and recognized in real time.

4. Real-Time Revenue Recognition
Based on the cost-based POC method, revenue is recognized proportionally as actual costs are incurred, providing a more accurate reflection of project progress.

5. Enhanced Reporting
Reporting at the contract item level is now fully supported. Using familiar apps like Service Actuals, Product and Service Margins and Service Plan/Actuals, you can view both planned and actual values from the contract and all its assigned items‚Äîoffering a complete financial picture.

üìà Why This Matters

This enhancement empowers service organizations to:

  • Improve financial accuracy and compliance
  • Gain deeper insights into contract performance
  • Streamline revenue recognition processes
  • Support more complex service delivery models

We‚Äôre thrilled to bring this capability to our customers and partners, helping you manage service contracts with greater precision and confidence.

üí¨ Have questions or want to share feedback? Join the conversation in our community forums!

entry.title: New Feature: Outbound Communication System Determination in SAP Sales & Service Cloud V2
entry.content:
• Overview
  • New UI: Communication System Determination
  • Create Determination Rules
  • Restrictions
  • Rule Configuration Options
  • Deletion
  • Multicast Behavior
  • Use cases for Outbound Communication System Determination
  • Sales Cloud Use Cases
  • Customer Service Use Cases
  • Enterprise Service Management (ESM) Use Cases
  • Outbound Configurations Supporting System Determination*
  • Watch: Configuring Outbound System Determinations

 

In SAP Sales & Service Cloud V1 (C4C), receiver determination for outbound messages was primarily handled using BADIs (Business Add-Ins). These BADIs allowed custom logic to route messages for instance to the correct ERP backend, such as SAP S/4HANA or SAP ERP, based on attributes like Sales Organization. While effective, this approach required technical development and lacked a dedicated UI for business users to manage rules easily.

 

Overview 

For SAP Sales & Service Cloud V2, a new feature, Outbound Communication System Determination has been introduced. This enhancement enables businesses to dynamically determine the receiver system for outbound messages based on configurable logic and entity attributes. 

For example, Business Partner or Functional Location can be replicated from ESM to specific S/4HANA tenants based on organisation structure or service area. This ensures seamless integration and greater flexibility for multi-system landscapes.

 

New UI: Communication System Determination 

A dedicated UI has been added under Settings titled Communication System Determination, providing a centralised place to manage determination rules.

 

Create Determination Rules 

Rule creation is a two-step process: 

  1. Create Communication System Determination
    Select a Type (Message) and an Outbound Configuration. 
  2. Add Rules 
    Under each determination, create one or more rules. 

Restrictions 

  • Only one determination per unique Type + Outbound Configuration can be added. 
  • For each determination, only one rule can be active at a time. 
  • A determination is active if it has an active rule. 
  • Activating a new rule automatically deactivates the previous active rule. 
  • Each rule must have at least one condition block.  

Rule Configuration Options 

  • Add condition blocks with multiple conditions (business expressions). 
  • Assign one, multiple, or all communication systems to each block. 
  • Add a Default block with only communication systems (no conditions). 

Deletion 

  • Delete rules under a determination. 
  • Delete entire determinations when no longer needed. 

Multicast Behavior  

For some outbound configurations, sending a message to multiple systems is not supported. 

  • All condition groups (except for Default) are evaluated together. 
  • Communication systems from groups that evaluate to true are selected for sending the message. 
  • Important: For outbound configurations where multicast is not supported if multiple condition groups evaluate true, the message will not be sent. 

 

Use cases for Outbound Communication System Determination 

Sales Cloud Use Cases 

  1. Sales Quote Routing Based on Sales OrganizationScenario: A sales quote created in Sales Cloud must be sent to the appropriate S/4HANA or ERP system based on the Sales Org. 
    Example: Quotes for Sales Org 1000 route to S/4HANA Tenant A; Sales Org 2000 route to ERP Tenant B.
     
  2. Order Replication for Multi-ERP Landscapes
    Scenario: Customer orders created in Sales Cloud need to be replicated to different ERP systems depending on distribution channel or division. 
    Example: Orders for digital channels go to S/4HANA; traditional retail orders go to SAP ERP. 
     
  3. Pricing Requests
    Scenario: When a quote requires pricing, the request should be sent to the correct backend system based on product category or region. 
    Example: High-tech products route to S/4HANA for advanced pricing; commodity products route to ERP. 
     
  4. Contract Creation
    Scenario: Sales contracts initiated in Sales Cloud must be replicated to the correct ERP system based on company code or customer group. 
    Example: Strategic accounts route to S/4HANA; legacy accounts route to ERP. 

  5. Multicast for Shared Product Catalog
    Scenario: Updates to product master data from Sales Cloud need to be sent to multiple ERP systems managing different regions. 
    Example: A global product update replicates to both S/4HANA and ERP tenants simultaneously.  


Customer Service Use Cases 

  1. Case Routing
    Scenario: A customer service case created in SAP Service Cloud needs to be replicated to the correct S/4HANA tenant based on the service organization or region. 
    Example: Cases for North America route to S/4HANA Tenant A, while cases for Europe route to Tenant B.
          
  2. Warranty Claim Processing
    Scenario: Warranty claims initiated in Service Cloud must be sent to the ERP system managing warranty contracts. 
    Logic: Determine the communication system based on product category or contract type. 
    Example: High-value equipment claims go to S/4HANA for advanced processing; standard claims go to legacy ERP.
     
  3. Field Service Integration
    Scenario: Service orders created for on-site repairs need to be replicated to the correct backend for resource planning. 
    Logic: Use functional location or installed base attributes to select the right S/4HANA tenant. 
    Example: Locations tied to Plant 1000 route to Tenant A; Plant 2000 routes to Tenant B.
     

Enterprise Service Management (ESM) Use Cases 

  1. Master Data Replication
    Scenario: Business Partner or Functional Location replication from ESM to multiple S/4HANA tenants. 
    Logic: Determine target system based on organization structure or service area. 
    Example: Partners linked to Shared Services Org replicated to Tenant A and Tenant B (multicast scenario).

  2. Service Order Distribution
    Scenario: Service orders created in ESM for global operations need to be routed to the correct backend for execution. 
    Logic: Use sales org, service org, or region attributes. 
    Example: Orders for APAC route to Tenant C; EMEA orders route to Tenant D.

  3. Multicast for Shared Asset Management
    Scenario: Functional location updates must be sent to multiple tenants managing shared assets. 
    Logic: Evaluate multiple condition groups and send updates to all applicable tenants. 
    Example: A shared plant replicated to both Tenant A and Tenant B for synchronized maintenance planning.

  4. HR Service Delivery Use Case
    Scenario: HR service requests (e.g., onboarding, payroll inquiries) in ESM need routing to the correct S/4HANA tenant in a shared services model. 
    Logic: Determine the communication system based on employee attributes like company code, location, or employment type. 
    Example: Onboarding request for Company Code 1010 ‚Üí S/4HANA Tenant A; Contractor payroll inquiry ‚Üí ERP Tenant C. 

 

Outbound Configurations Supporting System Determination* 

  • Replicate Registered Product to SAP S/4HANA 
  • Replicate Registered Product to SAP ERP 
  • Replicate Functional Location to SAP S/4HANA 
  • Replicate Business Partner Relationship to SAP S/4HANA 
  • Replicate Business Partner Relationship to SAP ERP 
  • Replicate Business Partner to SAP S/4HANA 
  • Replicate Business Partner to SAP ERP 

 Support for outbound configurations related to Opportunity, Quote, and Order will be available soon.  

 * As of 30.10.2025. List will be updated as support for more outbound configurations is added 

 

Watch: Configuring Outbound System Determinations

 

SAP Sales Cloud Version 2  SAP Service Cloud Version 2 SAP Field Service Management SAP SuccessFactors Enterprise Service Management

entry.title: Re: Tutorial Use Machine Learning to Extract Information from Documents with Swagger UI - error 500
entry.content: Hi Tri, can you kindly leverage a bit more on the question? I have tried it by myself, strictly following the tutorial here: https://developers.sap.com/tutorials/cp-aibus-dox-booster-key.html, i.e. creating a new trial account (new global account), then running the booster and following the examples from https://developers.sap.com/tutorials/cp-aibus-dox-web-oauth-token.html and https://developers.sap.com/tutorials/cp-aibus-dox-swagger-ui.html to create a successful request. It can potentially be that you have multiple instances in the subaccount or encountered an onboarding error before? Then, I recommend to simply create a completely new trial account and following the tutorial again. If you still encounter issues, you can also use our support tooling: https://help.sap.com/docs/document-information-extraction/document-information-extraction/getting-support and tell us at least your region information and global id and subaccount id, and the request you're trying (which endpoint?). Hope, this helps.

entry.title: For active yard management in warehouse enter a Checkpoint
entry.content:
Hi @JuergenPitz / SCM Community

I have integrated EWM with DAS and have activated YM for my warehouse.

I have found the previous Q&A (linked below) which provides an answer to the error message I am receiving in a qRFC.

Solved: Not able to perform check-in using Shipping Cockpi... - SAP Community

Process steps are as follows,

  1. Created a an inbound TU with Inbound Delivery assigned which has in turn created an appointment in DAS.
  2. Processed the appointment in DAS and set the status of the appointment to Arrived at Checkpoint (status light is Green in DAS)
  3. qRFC in EWM with message For active yard mgmnt in warehouse XXXX enter a Checkpoint

As I have a queue in EWM how can rectify this so EWM receives the update from DAS. The TU linked to the appointment should be arrived at checkpoint and the status should therefore changed from 'Planned' to 'Active'

Any thoughts/suggestions please?

Thanks

Michael

entry.title: Re: I can't create any Business User when I click on "Add...
entry.content:
In order to create Business Users, first you have to create a worker in Manage Workforce or via other data sources, you can check it here.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0bebd08dffca45afa67b1f751199afd0/f388e2a814b94899a2028ab5dc0f1c65.html

Once you created a worker in Manage Workforce you can click on the "Maintain Business users" button, or you can simply go to Maintain Business Users app and click on the "add" button, and the new worker will appear.

entry.title: SAP User Experience Update: What‚Äôs New for SAP S/4HANA 2025 (Private Cloud and On-Premise)
entry.content:
SAP S/4HANA 2025 comes with a whole host of user experience innovations and improvements.  Web access via My Home and the SAP Fiori launchpad has many useful improvements, as does SAP Mobile Start for mobile access. Joule gives conversational access to Private Cloud Edition using natural language, now also with analytical insights. There are additional collaboration capabilities, and many improvements in details: some towards providing a more consistent and integrated SAP Business Suite, some simply making a user‚Äôs life easier. Finally, design and UI technology is also advancing, with powerful AI support for developers now available.

This post covers:

  • UX Updates for Consistent and Integrated Business Suite
  • Web access: My Home and SAP Fiori launchpad
  • Mobile access: SAP Mobile Start
  • Joule
  • Situation Handling news
  • AI-Assisted capabilities: outlook
  • New collaboration capabilities
  • UX improvements in details
  • UI adaptation improvements for key users
  • Design and Technology news

If you want to get an impression of how good SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, looks across all the main product areas, have a look at the online Product Tour.

Since this post covers what‚Äôs new, building on the previous 2023 release, you might want to have a look at the UX innovations which came with the Feature Pack Stacks 00, 01 and 02 of the 2023 release:

  • SAP User Experience Update: What‚Äôs New for SAP S/4HANA 2023 (Private Cloud and On-Premise).
  • User Experience Advances with SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS01 (Private Cloud and On-Premise).
  • SAP User Experience Q4/2024 News for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2023.

For a full overview of what‚Äôs new since the FPS00 shipment of the 2023 release, have a look at the documentation (note that it includes features from the above 2023 FPS01 and FPS02 blog posts, as well as this one):

  • What‚Äôs New for SAP Fiori launchpad for SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

 

UX Updates for Consistent and Integrated Business Suite

We aim to provide a consistent and integrated experience for all users of the SAP Business Suite, which means providing an entry point for users to access all the various SAP products within the suite, and ensuring that the user experience across these products is consistent, making it easy for users to use applications from different products.

Entry Points

Figure 1 shows our approach for providing a web and a native mobile entry point to the products of the suite, such as SAP S/4HANA Cloud. I‚Äôd like to highlight that Joule can also be seen as an entry point to access the entire suite, since our goal is to provide Joule wherever you are, be it in our web applications or native mobile apps. Using Joule, our goal is to allow users to query and perform actions on all the products and applications which they are authorized to use, simply using natural language. As you‚Äôll see below, we are making good progress towards this goal.

Figure 1: Entry points providing an integrated workplace for accessing the SAP Business Suite. Alt Text: Image showing Joule on the left, ‚Äúavailable web and mobile‚Äù, and on the right a diagram with boxes indicating that SAP Mobile Start, SAP Start, and SAP Build Work Zone provide central access to SAP, with three boxes below for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, SAP SuccessFactors and Other SAP Products.

Web Central Access

I have covered recent UX innovations in our web central entry points, such as SAP Start and SAP Build Work Zone, and central services such as SAP Task Center, in my recent cloud UX blog posts. Since these capabilities also apply to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition as well as SAP S/4HANA (except for SAP Start), I will not repeat them here, but rather refer you to them:

  • SAP User Experience Q1/2025 Update ‚Äì Part 1: Many New Innovations Available (AI, Joule and More).
  • SAP UX Q3/2025 Update ‚Äì Part 1: AI, Joule, SAP Build Work Zone, SAP Mobile Start.

 What we will look at in this post in detail are UX innovations for local access from web or mobile, via My Home and the SAP Fiori launchpad, and via SAP Mobile Start. Each has a dedicated section further below.

Design Updates for Suite Consistency

To achieve consistency across the suite, we have made design improvements which are relevant for a consistent user experience across the entire SAP Business Suite, and which are now available with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025 and SAP S/4HANA 2025. As I mentioned in my April blog post Upcoming Design Updates for the SAP Business Suite (SAP Fiori for Web), consistency of the user experience across the various applications used by a user is an important part of overall usability, helping users to feel confident and at ease when using a suite of products ‚Äì no unexpected surprises.

In this section, we‚Äôll look at four design updates provided by the SAP Fiori launchpad, as well as examples of the new design for illustrations:

  • Navigation menu: Side navigation
  • Updated shell bar
  • Updated user menu
  • Updated notifications
  • New illustrations design

Navigation Menu: Side Navigation

Many SAP products already offer a navigation menu on the left of the screen, a pattern already familiar to many people. Hence, we have decided to apply that approach to navigation across the SAP Business Suite in upcoming releases.

In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA, the side navigation is displayed as an overlay, as you can see in Figure 2. It gives you direct access to your favorite apps, either directly or via the folders you have created. It also gives you direct access to your Spaces and Pages. The previously available menu to access all your spaces and pages along with personalization options is available via the entry ‚ÄúAll Spaces‚Äù at the bottom of the menu.

A big benefit of this new navigation menu is that you can now access your favorite apps directly from any application. Previously, you would have to return to My Home and then click on your favorite app, now you can access it directly from the menu, as shown in Figure 2.

Figure 2: The new navigation menu, opened up from the new shell bar, showing direct access to Favourite Apps, My Spaces and All Spaces. Alt Text: an image showing a list of sales orders and on the left a pop-over with a navigation menu with the sections already mentioned. Below the ‚ÄúFavourite App‚Äù eight apps are listed as well as two folders for favorite apps, plus the folder ‚ÄúInsights‚Äù for the insight tiles.

New Shell Bar ‚Äì need to switch it on!

The new shell bar design for the SAP Business Suite is available for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. The immediately visible difference is that now the product name is displayed to the right of the SAP Logo, in this case ‚ÄúS/4HANA Cloud‚Äù as you can see at the top of Figure 2. The logo and the name are all contained within a clickable area, which brings the user to the start page (e.g. My Home).

The new shell bar enables the next two design updates to the user menu and to notifications.

By default, after upgrading, the old shell bar will be shown, with the new navigation menu. We advise that you check any test automation and RPA (Robotic Process Automation) you may have before switching on the new shell bar, since you may need to make some adjustments ‚Äì in particular if you log off at the end of a test.

You can switch on the new shell bar via the Activate New Features application, with the feature ‚Äú/UI2/SHELL_BAR_TOGGLE‚Äù.

Updated User Menu

The new user menu design shown in Figure 3 provides more space for the avatar of the user, and provides more space between items for easier selection. The settings are always at the top as the first entry, and the ‚ÄúSign Out‚Äù option is separated from the actual navigation options in the list, to make it easier to find.

 Figure 3: Updated design of user menu and notifications. Alt Text: On the left an image of the previous user menu and the updated user menu. On the right an image of the updated notifications list, showing four notifications in the group ‚ÄúLast Month‚Äù, each with a title, two lines of description and a line with the data and a ‚Äúmore‚Äù link.

Updated Notifications Design

The new simplified design of notifications shown on the right in Figure 3 fits better with the overall design of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA, and provides simpler interactions. By default notifications are sorted by date, with grouping by ‚ÄúToday‚Äù, ‚ÄúYesterday‚Äù, ‚ÄúLast Week‚Äù, ‚ÄúLast Month‚Äù. Users can also choose to sort by importance.

New Illustrations Design

We have modernized the design of our illustrations, and also made them easier to understand. Figure 4 shows two examples ‚Äì one for indicating that something went wrong (the fallen ice cream cone), one for search, with an example of where the search illustration is used when opening a list report application without any filter values defined.

 Figure 4: Examples of new illustrations. Alt Text: On the left top three different size illustrations showing an ice cream cone fallen on the ground; bottom left an illustration of a globe with a magnifying glass, representing ‚Äúsearch‚Äù. On the right an image of a list report showing the search illustration since no data has been selected.

 

Web Access: My Home and SAP Fiori Launchpad

The 2025 release brings a number of improvements in My Home, the start page in the SAP Fiori launchpad, as well as some improvements in the launchpad itself (beyond the design updates mentioned above) ‚Äì for users as well as for administrators.

My Home

Here is an overview of the enhancements with this release:

  • To-Dos:
    • Tasks: Enhanced workflow relevant information and in-place actions
    • Situations from both standard and extended framework- are displayed
  • Intelligent homepage experience to boost productivity (cloud only):
    • Intelligent app recommendations.
    • Intelligent generation of pre-delivered cards.
  • Improved user experience: 
    • Drag & drop is now enabled in the insights section, so you can directly rearrange your tiles and cards.
    • Information about deprecated apps: any such apps are marked with an ‚Äúdeprecated2 icon .
  • Manage News application.

 This collection of videos shows the individual features of My Home ‚Äì both new and already existing ones:

  • My Home - Deep Dive (video collection)

Figure 5: My Home in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025 and SAP S/4HANA2025. Alt Text: A screenshot showing all the sections of My Home: To-Dos with tabs for Tasks (selected) and Situations;, a row with News on the left and Pages showing 8 pages on the right; Apps, with tabs for Favorites (selected ‚Äì showing 2 folders and 7 apps), Most Used, Recently Used, Recommended; Insight Tiles, showing 8 tiles; Insights Cards, showing 4 cards, 1 with a list and 3 with charts.

To-Dos Enhancements

The To-Dos task cards now offer action buttons, for example to approve or reject items. Often, this requires some key information about the item, for example the name of the product and the value for a purchase requisition. These details are now visualized directly in the task cards, as you can see in Figure 5, making the workflow more efficient.

To-Dos now also shows custom Situations, created using the extended Situation Handling framework, in addition to the standard situations delivered by SAP.

Intelligent Homepage Experience

Another useful new feature is AI recommendations for applications: as you can see in Figure 5 in the Apps section of My Home, a new tab Recommended has been introduced which uses AI to create a list of applications which are recommended to the user to add to their Favorites.

To help users get started with My Home, we provide intelligent generation of pre-delivered cards, so that when they first log on, the Insights Cards section is not blank, but rather has a number of pre-delivered cards relevant to the user‚Äôs role.

Manage News Application

I‚Äôm glad to announce that administrators can now easily create their own news to be displayed on My Home, using the new Manage News application. Figure 6 shows the start page of the application, listing news articles.

You can specify title, subtitle and main text, a background image, the start and end dates, as well as categorizing and targeting the news for specific groups of users or roles. Also, you can mark a news article as being ‚ÄúCritical‚Äù, so that it is highlighted accordingly. You can see an example in Figure 5.

Figure 6: Manage News application. Alt Text: Screenshot of the Manage News application, showing a filter bar and a list of two news articles with their title, subtitle, footer text, criticality, status ‚Äúpublished‚Äù and publish start and end dates.

To get a better impression of how it works, watch this video:

  • Video: Manage News Application in My Home for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (2:00 min.)

You can find out more about these My Home innovations here:

  • My Home documentation.

SAP Fiori Launchpad

The launchpad provides more than just the spaces and pages for finding and starting apps: it provides the runtime shell in which all the applications run, and hence the updates mentioned above such as the new navigation, the new shell bar and user menu. It also controls navigation between apps, as well as settings such as which theme to apply. Here are some additional improvements with the 2025 release. 

Automatic high-contrast and dark-mode detection, also for custom themes

Users can define on their front-end device‚Äôs operating system whether applications should appear in a light mode or a dark mode, or a high-contrast mode. Now these settings are taken into account also for custom themes, in addition to SAP visual themes.

Technically this is done by the launchpad supporting theme sets, which is a group of themes of the same family with different flavors ‚Äì such as the Horizon theme, with a light and dark version along with high contrast black and high contrast white versions. Customers can create their own theme sets using the UI theme designer. Have a look at the documentation:

  • Managing Your Settings (see the setting Appearance).

Hiding empty pages and spaces

The apps which a user sees on a page on the SAP Fiori launchpad, and the pages which appear in a space, depend on a user‚Äôs authorizations. This can lead to a page being defined in such a way that certain users are not authorized to use any of the apps therein; similarly, a space can end up not having any pages available to a user. Now, if this happens, any such empty pages or spaces are hidden from the user, rather than being shown empty. Find out more here:

  • SAP Fiori launchpad: Hiding empty spaces and pages.

Update for Administrators of SAP Fiori Launchpad

Redesign of Apps for Managing Spaces and Pages

Up until now, the apps ‚ÄúManage Launchpad Spaces‚Äù and ‚ÄúManage Launchpad Pages‚Äù distinguished between entries which could be edited within a given tenant and entries which could only be used as templates when creating new spaces or pages. The editable ones were listed in the tab ‚ÄúCustomer-Created‚Äù, the others in the tab ‚ÄúPredefined‚Äù.

Our customers gave us feedback that this was in fact confusing, because a page which was listed as ‚ÄúCustomer-Created‚Äù in a non-productive tenant and which was transferred to a productive tenant became ‚ÄúPredefined‚Äù there, i.e. it was not listed under ‚ÄúCustomer-Created‚Äù despite it being customer-created.

Now, the design has been changed, with two tabs for editable entities (spaces or pages) and non-editable ones. For example, in the app ‚ÄúManage Launchpad Pages‚Äù, the tabs are called ‚ÄúPages‚Äù and ‚ÄúPage Templates‚Äù, as shown in Figure 8. No matter what tenant you are in, you cannot change or edit page templates, you can only use them to create new pages. The same applies to spaces in the Manage Launchpad Spaces app.

Figure 8: The redesigned app Manage Launchpad Pages with Tabs for ‚ÄúPages‚Äù and ‚ÄúPage Templates‚Äù. Alt Text: image shows an extract of the app showing the two tabs.

Role-dependent Launchpad Configuration Parameters

We provide administrators a new option to apply launchpad settings role-based, so that different roles can have different settings being applied. This can be helpful if a specific group of users need different settings, for example if you want to gradually introduce Spaces and Pages, you no longer have to switch it on for all users. Find out more, and further examples, in the documentation:

  • Setting Parameters per Profile

Joule User Experience Innovations

Joule is the AI-powered copilot for SAP‚Äôs cloud products, offering a powerful new user experience, using natural language to access them and providing a nice flow for the user wherever they are, on desktop, laptop or mobile devices.

First, we‚Äôll have a look at the latest generic or cross-product UX innovations in the web and mobile, before I give you some pointers to the product-specific innovations as well as news about developing custom capabilities.

Cross-Product Joule UX Innovations

This section covers these user experience innovations:

  • Joule Analytical Pattern.
  • Joule supports multiple conversations.
  • Use Joule in 11 languages.
  • Joule in Microsoft 365 Copilot and Microsoft Teams
  • Customer specific skills and agents.

Joule Analytical Pattern

This new pattern is available in all products which give users access to our Joule copilot. This new pattern is powered by SAP Analytics Cloud, with data from models that are indexed by the Just Ask feature of SAP Analytics Cloud.

Figure 12: Example Joule Analytical Pattern. Alt Text: an animated GIF showing how a user asks Joule ‚ÄúShow me sales commission by agend for model bike sales‚Äù, and how Joule shows a horizontal bar chart for top 5 sales commissions per sales agent.

As you can see in figure 12, users can now access analytical insights from the product they are working in, without having to first navigate to SAP Analytics Cloud, making work more efficient and hence also more enjoyable.

The example in figure 12 is what we call a descriptive question, but Joule can respond to a wide range of queries:

  • Descriptive questions, such as ‚ÄúWhat is the total revenue for Q1?‚Äù or ‚ÄúShow me sales by region in 2025‚Äù.
  • Comparative analysis, such as ‚ÄúCompare sales between 2023 and 2024" Or How do profits in Germany compare to France?‚Äù
  • Time series analysis, such as ‚ÄúShow me sales by month‚Äù or ‚ÄúShow the trend of customer acquisitions over the last 6 months‚Äù.
  • Top / Bottom N analysis, such as ‚ÄúShow me top 5 sales by store‚Äù or ‚ÄúList the bottom 3 regions in terms of sales‚Äù.

Find out more in this blog post:

  • Introducing Analytical Insights in Joule: Empowering Smarter Decisions, Instantly.

With the introduction of this new pattern, Joule now supports four interaction patterns:

  1. Informational pattern, for querying written documents, such as SAP documentation in the SAP Help Portal, or customer policies etc.
  2. Navigational pattern, for finding and navigating to applications.
  3. Transactional pattern, for interacting directly with business applications.
  4. Analytical pattern, for answering analytical queries directly in Joule.

Joule Supports Multiple Conversations

When having a conversation with Joule, you can ask follow-up questions, building on the previous questions and answers in the conversation, since Joule keeps the context.

Now you can initiate up to ten conversations in parallel, with Joule keeping the context for each of the conversations, so that when you return to a previous conversation you can continue where you left off. Figure 13 shows what this looks like.

Figure 13: Joule supports multiple conversations. On the left, a conversation was started by asking ‚ÄúHow many languages does Joule support‚Äù. On the right, you see how active and expired conversations are shown. Alt Text: On the left, Joule replies with ‚ÄúJoule currently supports eleven language officially‚Äù and then lists them, below the answer a link to the source document ‚ÄúJoule Multi Language Support‚Äù is provided. On the right, the conversation history sidebar is visible on the left, overlaying half the screen, with a button ‚Äú+ New Conversation‚Äù at the top, followed by a section ‚ÄúActive‚Äù with two conversations and a section ‚ÄúExpired‚Äù with four. The bottom contains a link to ‚ÄúSettings‚Äù and on to ‚ÄúAI Notice‚Äù.

 You can return to conversations within 8 hours. To start a new conversation, simply click on ‚ÄúNew Conversation‚Äù. The old conversation will be listed in the ‚ÄúActive‚Äù section, as you can see in Figure 13. The title of the conversation is automatically created by Joule using AI; users can rename the titles when they return to the conversation.  Joule supports a maximum of 10 active conversations.

After 8 hours, the conversation expires but is not deleted. It is kept read-only in the ‚ÄúExpired‚Äù section, as shown in Figure 13. Conversations are finally deleted 7 days after the creation date.

In the browser, Joule can be expanded to fill the screen, as shown in Figure 14.

Intelligent Situation Handling news

Intelligent Situation Handling speeds up the resolution of critical business situations by automatically and hence proactively alerting users about urgent issues, proposing follow-up actions, letting you monitor situations, and automating the resolution by using business rules.

If you‚Äôre not familiar with Intelligent Situation Handling, I recommend that you watch the introductory video and read the ‚ÄúGet started‚Äù blog posts on the SAP Community topic page:

  • Intelligent Situation Handling topic page.

 With the 2025 release, SAP provides nine new situation templates in the areas of finance, public sector, service, sourcing and procurement, and supply chain:

  • New use cases for Situation Handling.

 For the full list of available templates provided by SAP, look here:

  • Use Cases for Situation Handling.

New Situation Handling Framework Capabilities

Already with the 2023 release we made it possible for partners and customers to create their own situation objects with ABAP Development Tooling (ADT) via developer extensibility. This becomes even more powerful with the 2025 release, with the extended framework supporting the collection of data context, support for custom objects in your own use cases, and support for the standard translation option. Let‚Äôs have a look at these in a bit more detail.

Data Context supported by the Extended Framework

The data context is business data from business objects involved in a situation instance that can be collected, distributed, and used for advanced analytics ‚Äì for example using the Monitor Situations ‚Äì Extended app. If enabled in a situation type, data context is collected when a situation instance is created, updated, or completed. For example, If you use the situation template Quantity Deficit in Supplier's Delivery to inform specific members in your purchasing organization about a deficit in the quantity of materials to be delivered by the supplier, you'll get, for example, the material, plant, or supplier as part of the data context.

With the 2025 release, every extended object-based situation template supports data context. You can activate it in the Manage Situation Types - Extended app. Doing so results in an event being triggered that includes the data context every time a situation instance is created, updated or completed. For more information, look at the documentation:

  • Data Context (documentation).
  • Data Context in the What‚Äôs New documentation.

Custom Object Types Supported

You can now use custom object types and object node types, that you have created with the ABAP development tools for Eclipse (ADT), in situation objects in the Manage Situation Objects app as well as in ADT. Until now, you could only use those delivered by SAP. Hence you have far more flexibility in supporting your own Situation Handling use cases.

Translation with Standard Function Supported

With this feature, you can use the standard function for translating texts included in situation objects, situation scenarios, and situation types. This means that you now can use the Maintain Translations app, so that all your translation work can be done in a consistent way now. Find out more in the documentation:

  • Translate Texts from Situation Objects, Situation Scenarios, and Situation Types.

UX Improvements in Details

As I never tire of saying: the details matter if you want to provide a great UX! We continue to work on these details, which can often result in higher satisfaction for users. With the 2025 release, we bring you a large number of improvements, as outlined in the following subsections. Note that we have four interesting ones related to working with tables towards the end of this section.

New Options for Filtering Dates (Semantic Date Range)

We have two new features here:

  • We now offer the semantic date range also for selecting dates in the table settings dialog, if you want to define a specific filter on a given field in the table. (Note that the table settings dialog allows you to define filters on all the fields in the table, irrespective of which fields appear in the filter bar at the top of the screen).
  • I‚Äôm pleased to say that, on request of many users, we now provide the option to define filters on date fields for the ‚ÄúLast X days/weeks/months/‚Ä¶ to date‚Äù as well as the ‚ÄúNext X days/weeks/months/‚Ä¶ to date‚Äù, where users can specify the number ‚ÄúX‚Äù.

An example of how tricky such seemingly simple things can be: if, on December 11th, you choose ‚ÄúLast 2 months to date‚Äù, do you mean the period from November 1st to December 11th, which would be up to the current date but not a full two months, or do you mean ‚Äúthe last two full months‚Äù, i.e. October 1st to November 30th? Since both make sense, the selection screen gives users the option to choose, with the default being the ‚Äúfull month‚Äù case, described as ‚Äúexclude current period‚Äù, as you can see in Figure 20.

Column Size Persisted in Flexible Column Layout

When users open up an application which uses the Flexible Column Layout, it will now remember where the user had placed the separator last time, rather than putting it in the default position. Figure 21 shows an example where at the top you see the default position, and below you see the separator moved to the right slightly, so that all the text is visible in the table on the left. Next time the app is opened, the separator will open in the same place.

Figure 21: Flexible Column Layout now remembers the previously used column width. The image at the top shows the default column width, the image below shows the last column width the user chose. Alt Text: two images of Manage Cost Centers application is shown, the upper one has the separator bar between the list on the left and the details on the right further to the left than the image on the right.

This feature was requested by many customers, and I am happy to announce that it is now available: all the help texts for individual fields which are stored in the back-end data dictionary are now available to users using the built-in help, powered by SAP Companion. In other words, users of SAP Fiori apps have access to the same help texts as were shown with the classic UIs such as SAP GUI. You can see an example in Figure 22.

Documentation of Keyboard Shortcuts within Applications

Power users are often quicker when only using the keyboard, rather than switching back and forth between keyboard and mouse ‚Äì but only if they know all the relevant keyboard shortcuts. With the 2508 release we provide information about available keyboard shortcuts directly where you need them, in the context of the application. By selecting ‚ÄúKeyboard Shortcuts‚Äù in the user menu, a new window appears explaining all the available shortcuts for the application area currently in focus. If you click on a different part of the application, or navigate somewhere else, then the window showing the available shortcuts is updated immediately for the new context.

Figure 23 shows an example for Manage Journal Entries, where the focus is currently on the filter bar. Clicking on the the table results in many more shortcuts being shown, for example for the arrow keys for moving up and down etc., as shown in Figure 24.

Figure 23: In-context documentation of keyboard shortcuts, for the filter bar. Alt Text: A screenshot of the app ‚ÄúManage Journal Entries‚Äù with the focus on the filter bar, with a second window on the right containing Keyboard Shortcuts in two groups, ‚ÄúGlobal Shortcuts‚Äù and ‚ÄúGeneric Keyboard Interactions‚Äù.

Figure 24: In-context documentation of keyboard shortcuts, for the table. Alt Text: A screenshot of the app ‚ÄúManage Journal Entries‚Äù with the focus on the table, with a second window on the right containing Keyboard Shortcuts in two groups, ‚ÄúGlobal Shortcuts‚Äù and ‚ÄúJournal Entries (43,854)‚Äù. The latter contains descriptions for shortcuts for the table, such as the arrow up, down, left, right keys, or using ‚ÄúCmd + D‚Äù to delete.

Automatic Update of SAP Fiori Apps Upon Change of Data in Backend

There are quite a few cases where users would appreciate seeing absolutely up-to-date data in their application, so that the data is automatically updated if changes occur in the backend. These changes could be made by other users, or by automated background processing . An example for the latter is the Traceability Results application, which is now automatically updated if a batch run has created new traceability items.

Note that this only supported by applications built with SAP Fiori elements using OData V4.

Improved performance for scrolling in grid tables

Our engineers have done some magic so that now scrolling is very fast in grid tables, which are the table type typically used for working with large volumes of data.

Why do I call it magic? Well, modern web-based UIs have the UI layer running in the browser, managing direct user interactions, and calling services in the backend to get and update data. However, if you are working with a list of say over 100,000 items, you would have to wait quite a long time when starting the application until all items have been loaded into the browser. Hence we only load a certain number to start with, such as 100. This however means that when a user scrolls beyond the 100 which have been loaded, additional data needs to be fetched from the backend, which slows down scrolling. Now, our engineers have found a way to minimize this effect to almost zero, so that you have fast scrolling all the time ‚Äì magic!

Figure 25: Performance improvement for scrolling in grid tables. Alt Text: a short video showing scrolling through a grid table.

Whenever the threshold is reached and more data needs to be loaded, there is a very short delay, with the progress indicator being shown for a few milliseconds, as you can see in Figure 25. In most cases, this is completely negligible. Nevertheless, we do also provide customers the option to change the number of entries loaded by default when the application is started. This is useful if a customer knows that, for a certain application, the number of entries will not exceed 2.000 for example. Then they can set the threshold to 2.000, which means that the application will take a little bit longer to load first time around, but then scrolling will be instantaneous for all the data. Figure 26 shows the UI for doing this, as part of UI adaptation. The ‚ÄúThreshold‚Äù determines the maximum number of entries loaded when the application is started, the ‚ÄúScroll Threshold‚Äù determines the maximum number that are loaded during scrolling if new entries need to be fetched.

Figure 26: UI adaptation to determine the threshold determining the maximum number of entries loaded in a table when an application is started. Alt Text: A screenshot with a pop-over ‚ÄúConfigure Table‚Äù with two new fields ‚ÄúThreshold‚Äù, being edited with the value 3000, and ‚ÄúScroll Threshold‚Äù, containing the value 300.

Table Grouping and/or ‚ÄúShow more per row‚Äù State can be Shared

If a user personalizes a table by grouping entries by one of the fields, such as the date, this grouping is persisted when sharing the link with a colleague: when the colleague opens the application with the link, they see the same grouping applied.

Similarly, if ‚Äúshow more per row‚Äù was selected by the user before sharing the link, the recipient will also see more information per row upon opening the application via the link. This information is also stored when saving a view of a table.

Sort or Group Tables by ID or Description

SAP Fiori apps display the ID and the description in the same column within a table, which provides a better experience than having them in two separate columns.

Now, we offer users a choice when sorting or grouping the table by a column which contains both ID and description: they can choose to do this by ID or by description. As you can see in Figure 27, this selection is very intuitive. The example shows what it looks like when sorting by Company Code. At the bottom of the table you see an entry ‚Äú1710 (BestRun US)‚Äù, where the Company Code (the ID) is 1710 and the Company Name (the Description) is ‚ÄúBestRun US‚Äù. In the popover ‚ÄúSort By‚Äù section, the row of icons next to Company Code and Company Name indicate that currently no sorting is active, with the option to sort either bei Code or by Name ascending or descending.

Figure 27: Sort or group tables by ID (in this case Company Code) or by Description (Company Name) when both are displayed together in one column . Alt Text: A screenshot of part of the Manage Journal Entries app, with a list of journal entries and a pop-over ‚ÄúColumn Settings‚Äù with two sections ‚ÄúSort By‚Äù and ‚ÄúGroup By‚Äù. The ‚ÄúSort By‚Äù section has two lines, ‚ÄúCompany Code‚Äù and ‚ÄúCompany Name‚Äù, and offers three buttons with icons for each of these, representing ‚Äúno sorting‚Äù, ‚Äúascending‚Äù, ‚Äúdescending‚Äù.

Hiding Description Fields in List of Fields in Table Settings

For tables as above where ID and description are displayed in one column, technically, the ID and description are stored in two different fields. Until now, when users personalize the table, both the ID and the description were listed in the list of columns, which confused some users.

Now, we have addressed this by providing the option to hide the descriptions (see Figure 28), and hence simplifying personalization. This option is on by default, i.e. the description fields are automatically hidden now.

Figure 28: Description fields can be hidden from the list of fields shown when personalizing tables. Alt Text: A screenshot with a pop-over ‚ÄúView Settings‚Äù containing tabs ‚ÄúColumns‚Äù, ‚ÄúSort‚Äù, ‚ÄúFilter‚Äù, and a pop-over ‚ÄúFilters‚Äù with two options ‚ÄúHide descriptions‚Äù (selected) and ‚ÄúHide Unselected‚Äù (deselected) . ‚ÄúColumns‚Äù is selected and shows a list of columns with check marks. The third entry is ‚ÄúCompany Code‚Äù, followed by ‚ÄúCreated On‚Äù ‚Äì i.e. the description column ‚ÄúCompany Name‚Äù is not listed next to the ‚ÄúCompany Code‚Äù.

These are the highlights of our changes in details. For the full list of what‚Äôs new since the FPS00 shipment of the 2023 release, have a look at the What‚Äôs New Viewer:

  • What‚Äôs New for SAP Fiori launchpad for SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

 

UI adaptation improvements for key users

We have made significant enhancements to UI Adaptation for key users with the 2025 release. The ‚ÄúAdapt UI‚Äù option which key users see in their user menu shows you what you can change in the app, in a very intuitive way. And you can change and adapt far more than in the past. See below for some highlights.

Also good to know: the Adapt UI menu entry is also available when using a Classic app (SAP GUI for HTML) from within the SAP Fiori launchpad. It will bring up the Adapt UI app for Screen Personas F5740 Adapt UI for Classic Applications with Screen Personas, which allows key users to adapt the layout of these classic UIs.

Key Users Can Rearrange ID and Description Within a Field or Column

SAP applications come with a standard arrangement of ID and description within a field or a column, based on user research. We have found that for financial users, it is usually best to have the ID first and the description in brackets: Company Code (Company Description), for example ‚Äú1710 (BestRun US)‚Äù as shown in Figure 27. For users in sales and logistics, it is usually best to have the name first and the ID in brackets: for example Customer Name (Customer ID), for example ‚ÄúUS Specialty Cycles 5 (USCU_S05)‚Äù as shown in Figure 2.

Now, key users can use UI adaptation to rearrange the order for a given application. Doing this change applies then to all occurrences of the field in the application, i.e. the filter bar, the table or in a form on an object page.

Far More Options for Key Users to Adapt UIs

Key users can now make far more significant changes to UIs than before. For example, they can add a button to clear all filter values in the filter bar, remove buttons such as the ‚ÄúExport to Excel‚Äù, and much more. Figure 29 shows the options for configuring a table for example.

Figure 29: Many more options for Key Users to adapt UIs. Alt Text: UI Adaptation is shown switched on for the application Manage Bank Hierarchies, with a popover called ‚ÄúConfigure Table‚Äù filling half the screen, and showing 12 options such as ‚ÄúEnable Table Export‚Äù, ‚ÄúFrozen Column Count‚Äù with a field for entering the number, ‚ÄúSorting‚Äù, ‚ÄúColumns‚Äù etc.

 

Design and Technology News

For a comprehensive overview of the recent design and technology news, have a look at my blog posts from Q1 and Q3 2025. These are also relevant for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA 2025 release, since the design and technology are already available in the cloud:

  • SAP User Experience Q1/2025 Update ‚Äì Part 7: UI Design and Technology for Web and Mobile
  • SAP UX Q3/2025 Update ‚Äì Part 7: UI Design and Technology for Web and Mobile
    Note though that the SAP Build Extensibility Wizard presented there is currently only integrated with for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

We are progressing at such a pace, that I have some additional news to share with you, not covered by the above posts. In addition, I would like to explicitly mention some particular highlights here from the above posts too.

Regarding extensibility: do have a look at the new SAP Extensibility Explorer.

SAP Design System Portal and UI Kits ‚Äì now with AI Components

We recently introduced the new SAP Design System portal that brings together the product design guidelines SAP Fiori for web, SAP Fiori for iOS, and SAP Fiori for Android, as well as to the new digital design system guidelines. With its enhanced usability, simplified versioning and improved performance, designers (and developers!) get a better user experience compared with the previous SAP Fiori design guidelines.

The new UI Kits available for designers in Figma make it easy for designers to design accessible UIs at enterprise scale, for web applications, mobile iOS and Android applications as well as wearables. The UI Kits provide reusable components for web and mobile, along with web floorplans, which give you what you need out-of-the-box.

We have just released SAP Web UI Kit v8.0 which includes a full set of AI components: AI Button, AI Menu Button, AI Split Menu Button, AI Prompt Input, AI Input, AI Text Area, and AI Rich Text Editor.

Figure 30: The SAP Design System portal start page (on the left), and SAP‚Äôs UI Kits for designers in Figma (on the right). Alt Text: Two screenshots. The portal page shows four main sections SAP Fiori for Web, ‚Ä¶ for Android, ‚Ä¶ for iOS, and SAP Digital Design System, each followed by links to UI elements, Figma kits, and overviews. The UI Kits show 8 cards, SAP Fiori for Android, Web, iOS, watchOS, Wear OS, Performance, Accessibility and SAP S/4HANA.

Find out more here:

  • New SAP Design System Portal for SAP Fiori Design Guidelines, and New UI Kits for Designers.

Using AI to Develop UIs

The above posts from Q1 and Q3 introduced a number of powerful ways to accelerate UI development by using AI, such as:

  • Creating SAP Fiori elements apps from a sketch (in the Q1 post), now integrated in SAP Build Code and Joule (Q3 post)
  • Joule for SAPUI5 freestyle development (Q1 post)
  • AI-assisted auto-fix of coding errors with UI5 linter (Q3 post)

Recently, we have gone even further and introduced MCP servers for freestyle SAPUI5 development as well as for developing with SAP Fiori elements and the associated building blocks. These open-source Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers provide AI agents with comprehensive UI5 and SAP Fiori elements knowledge, including best practices and project-aware context information, and thus provide developers with valuable support. Figure 31 shows examples. 

Figure 31: Examples of the UI5 MCP Server (on the left) and the MCP Server for SAP Fiori (on the right) in action. Alt Text: both images show screenshots of a CLINE console view with a task entered as text at the top, followed by a list of steps which the system proposes to do to solve the task.

 Read about these new MCP servers in these blog posts:

  • UI5 MCP Server.
  • MCP Server for SAP Fiori.

Accessibility taken to the next level: WCAG 2.2 support

Accessibility is key to using SAP's business solutions. Adopting the latest standards gives applications a true cutting edge, ensuring that solutions are inclusive and meet the diverse needs of users globally. When creating apps with SAP Build and SAPUI5, developers can leverage the latest Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 2.2.

For example, two of the key new requirements in the 2.2 version are:

  • The minimum target size of an interactive element now needs to be 24x24 px, so that users don‚Äôt accidentally activate a neighbouring element.
  • Each operation that can be performed by dragging can also be performed alternatively without dragging ‚Äì so that people who cannot use a mouse to drag can still use the UI.

See more details:

  • SAPUI5 is Leading the Way in Accessibility with WCAG 2.2 

Blue Crystal and Belize Themes No Longer Available in the Web

As announced in April (Upcoming Removal of SAP Fiori Themes Belize and Blue Crystal), the visual themes Blue Crystal and Belize have been removed from our web UI technology with the 2025 release of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA.

 After upgrading, existing usages of Belize or Blue Crystal will be automatically redirected to the Horizon theme.

If you have created your own custom theme based on Belize or Blue Crystal using the UI theme designer, you will need to migrate this to an available theme. Our strong recommendation is to base the new version on the Horizon theme.

For more information about the web UI technologies affected, and how to migrate custom themes, have a look at this blog post:

  • Announcement: Removal of Belize theme of SAP Fiori.

Note that SAP GUI for Windows continues to support older themes, including Blue Crystal and Belize.

 

Final words

Come join us at TechEd 2025, November 4 - 6, either virtually or in Berlin, or at one of the TechEd On The Road events in Louisville (USA), Bangalore (India) and Sydney (Australia), to find out more about our latest user experience innovations. I myself will be in Berlin and Bangalore, so feel free to approach me after my talks if you have any specific questions. I‚Äôm looking forward to meeting some of you!

 This blog posts gives an overview of all the UX related sessions at all four events:

  • Exciting UX talks at TechEd ‚Äì Virtual, or meet us in Berlin and On The Road (USA, India, Australia).

 Please continue using the community to share your learnings and best practices, either by posting articles yourselves or via comments on this post. You can also follow me in the community if you want to be notified about further similar updates from me.

entry.title: Navigating Oman‚Äôs Regulatory Evolution with SAP ERP HCM Localization
entry.content:
In today‚Äôs rapidly changing regulatory landscape, localization is more than a technical requirement - it‚Äôs a strategic enabler. SAP‚Äôs localization framework enables enterprises to remain compliant with country-specific mandates while driving operational efficiency and business continuity.

For Oman, this means aligning with recent key reforms such as the Social Protection Fund (SPF) and preparing for the anticipated introduction of Personal Income Tax (PIT).

Oman Localization Scope

SAP ERP HCM offers tailored localization features for Oman, supporting legal reporting, payroll processing, and statutory compliance. These features are designed to help businesses navigate regulatory changes with agility and confidence.

Key Features

  • Social Protection Fund (SPF): The establishment of Oman‚Äôs Social Protection Fund marks a major milestone in social reform. It brings multiple social security programs under one framework to strengthen coverage and sustainability. Implementation started on January 1, 2024, with phased timelines extending to 2028 for certain schemes. SAP ERP HCM supports this transformation by enabling the configuration and processing of Social Insurance schemes in line with legal requirements. For detailed documentation and configuration guidance, visit the SAP Help Portal.

 

  • Leaves and Absences: The system supports both standard and Oman-specific leave types; It also provides flexible capabilities for absence distribution, advance leave payments, provisioning, and granting.
  • Ticket Benefit: The solution provides the flexibility to implement benefits such as leave passage according to business needs. It allows defining eligibility, frequency, and cost parameters, integrated with payroll for accurate processing.
  • End-of-Service (EOS): The Oman local version allows the provisioning and calculation of end-of-service gratuity for employees in line with the law. The OMEOS feature evaluates eligibility based on termination reasons and ensures accurate settlements.
  • Wage Protection System (WPS): Compliance with Oman‚Äôs WPS is supported through the Oman WPS File Generation Report (HOMWPSF0), generating payment and bank details in the required format.

For detailed configuration guidance, please check out the SAP Help Portal.

Looking Ahead: Oman Personal Income Tax Introduction

Oman has officially introduced a Personal Income Tax Law, marking a historic fiscal shift in the Gulf region. Effective January 1, 2028, a 5% tax will apply to annual income exceeding OMR 42,000. This initiative supports Oman Vision 2040, which aims to diversify the economy and enhance fiscal sustainability.

SAP continues to monitor the progress of this reform and plans to include relevant functionalities - such as payroll tax calculation and reporting - as part of its future roadmap.

Stay Informed: Key Resources for Oman Localization

As Oman continues to modernize its social and fiscal systems, SAP remains committed to delivering timely and relevant updates. Stay connected and informed through the following resources:

  • SAP Build Work Zone: Access curated localization content, announcements, and collaboration spaces.
  • SAP Localization Community: Engage with SAP experts and subscribe to the Localization tag for the latest updates.
  • SAP Regulatory Change Manager: Stay up to date with legal changes and their impact on SAP solutions.

Feel free to share your thoughts or questions below. We would love to hear from you.

entry.title: What's New SAP Asset Performance Management 2510
entry.content:
With SAP Asset Performance Management 2510, we've enabled Streaming Analytics in the embedded IoT platform (currently available through the Early Adopter Care program), enabling incoming data points to be evaluated in real time. Additionally, Trigger Rules ensure relevant events automatically generate maintenance actions. For scheduled rules, the new configurable delay/offset guarantees that all data is considered before evaluation, reducing missed insights and improving reliability. On top of that, extended characteristic types - including numeric, date, currency, and time - make strategy-based class assignments more flexible. 

 

Contents

Near Real-Time Insights with Streaming Analytics and Trigger Rules in the Embedded IoT Platform
Configure Rule Offset for Data Ingestion Delays
Extended Characteristic Types for Strategy-Based Class Assignments
Integration with SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition

Near Real-Time Insights with Streaming Analytics and Trigger Rules in the Embedded IoT Platform

We have enabled Streaming Analytics in the embedded IoT platform,  helping you to process every incoming data point in real time ‚Äî enabling additional rules-based use cases. It is currently available through the  Early Adopter Care program.

Alongside this, a new Trigger Rule integration links Streaming Analytics directly to SAP Asset Performance Management (APM), ensuring that real-time insights can automatically generate maintenance actions. Together, these innovations bridge the gap between live IoT data and asset management processes.

Entry point to Streaming Analytics app in the Embedded IoT Platform

Why Streaming Analytics?

Traditional APM rules analyze data in batches, identifying trends and deviations over time. This is ideal for long-term monitoring, but sometimes you need to respond immediately.

That‚Äôs where Streaming Analytics comes in. It evaluates each data point the moment it enters the system, allowing you to:

  • Detect threshold violations in real time.
  • Preprocess data by rounding or smoothing sensor values.
  • Derive new indicators to enrich your asset model.
  • Convert machine alarms into APM alerts when needed.

So in a nutshell the difference is:

  • APM rules analyze data in batches‚Äîover hours or days‚Äîto find trends or deviations.
  • Streaming analytics evaluates each data point as it arrives, triggering instant actions such as alerts or maintenance tasks.

How It Works

Using the Analytics Builder in the embedded IoT platform, you can define streaming rules in a low-code environment. 

For example, you might create a rule that rounds temperature readings, defines a Preprocessed Temperature value, and triggers an alert when a threshold is exceeded.

The preprocessed values appear as new time-series data in the IoT device model and can be mapped to APM indicators, ensuring both raw and processed data are available for analysis and condition-based monitoring.

Example of IoT device model settings - preprocessed measurement values

Trigger Rule Integration with APM Rules

To ensure real-time insights lead to immediate action, a custom Trigger Rule output connects Streaming Analytics results with APM standard rules.

When a Streaming Analytics model detects a defined condition, the Trigger Rule can automatically activate a corresponding APM rule. That APM rule then performs its configured action ‚Äî such as creating an alert, generating a maintenance demand, or updating an asset‚Äôs condition status.

This integration keeps APM and IoT environments synchronized, so that events detected in near real time are instantly reflected in the asset management process.

Together, Streaming Analytics and Trigger Rules enable a continuous feedback loop between data detection, decision, and action:

  1. The IoT platform processes incoming data points in near real time.
  2. Streaming Analytics detects relevant events.
  3. Trigger Rules ensure those events automatically lead to actions in APM.

This combination gives you a faster and more connected approach to managing asset performance ‚Äî from sensor to action.

Watch this detailed demo to see how it works:

Click to watch video

For detailed information on Streaming Analytics application and analytics builder, refer to the SAP Help Portal and check out the official documentation from the Embedded IoT platform provider.

  • Streaming Analytics
  • Analytics Builder

 

Configure Rule Offset for Data Ingestion Delays

In condition monitoring, timing critical. For example, if rules run before all data has arrived, evaluations can be incomplete ‚Äî leading to missed insights or unreliable alerts. We've therefore introduced a configurable offset for scheduled rules, designed to ensure every data point counts.

With this enhancement, rules execute after the expected data arrival, based on the known ingestion pattern of each data source. Whether data comes through APIs with a 90-minute delay or through daily file uploads, you can now define an offset that aligns rule execution with real data availability.

This results in:

  • Complete and accurate evaluation of all data points
  • Reliable condition monitoring ‚Äì each point is evaluated once, no duplication or omissions
  • Flexible and customer-specific configuration for API- or file-based ingestion
  • Reduced operational risk through trusted, automated alerts and notifications

By aligning rule execution with the know data ingestion timing, you can have more confidence in your insights and automated monitoring. For more information see the SAP Help Portal Triggering a Rule.

Example of how to configure the rule offset

Watch this video for more details:

Watch the video

 

Extended Characteristic Types for Strategy-Based Class Assignments

Previously, APM only supported characteristic type Char with allowed values, limiting the ability to capture and utilize different types of data for technical objects. This made it harder for customers to accurately identify relevant object values and take timely maintenance actions. 

We now include Numeric, Date, Currency, and Time data type characteristics. These new characteristic types can be used when creating strategy-based class assignments, allowing more comprehensive and flexible data capture for technical objects.

Customers can now easily identify the associated values of technical objects across multiple data types and initiate the required maintenance more efficiently, improving asset management accuracy and operational reliability.

Example of new characteristic types for strategy assessment for classes

 

New OData APIs

To enhance the API offerings, GraphQL APIs Strategy Assessment for Classes and Failure Data Assessments will be deprecated as of October 21, 2026. We encourage you to migrate to the new Failure Data Assessment OData API that will cater to both strategy assessment for classes and RCM assessments.

For more information, refer to SAP Note 3603407 and APIs for Asset Reliability Engineering.

 

Integration with SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition

The 2025 release of SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition brings deeper integration with SAP Asset Performance Management (APM). APM recommendations, indicators, and assessments are now visible directly in the Find Technical Objects app, together with risk and criticality information. In addition, APM failure data relationships can now be used to select Failure Modes and Failure Effects during maintenance processes, ensuring the right task lists are assigned and actions are aligned with historical recommendations.

For full details, read Fernanda Rodrigues' blog Asset Management in SAP Cloud ERP Private 2025 Release and explore Fernanda's other blogs too.

 

Stay Informed and Get Involved

  • Find out what's up and coming in the SAP Road Map Explorer.
  • For an exhaustive list of all new features, visit the SAP Help Portal - What's New in SAP Asset Performance Management.. 
  • Send us your improvement requests. Submit or vote for the improvement you would like to see in the SAP Continuous Influence session.
  • Check the APM link collection. 

Let us know what you think about these new features - leave us a comment below or ask a question! 

See you soon for the 2511 update!
